But as Paul Willis explains , the consilience of evidence for theories such as cosmological inflation and global warming (and indeed many other kinds of beliefs) depends on what people mean by "experimentally tested" -- that is, they can be replicated experimentally. The scientific method offers a framework for testing a given hypothesis. Scientists don't just observe and test. We test. We try it, and we learn. That's how we discover things like black holes and dark matter, which scientists are now discovering more frequently thanks to advanced telescopes, supercomputers and other instruments.

SAN FRANCISCO ( Reuters ) - A U.S. judge on Tuesday ruled in favor of the National Security Agency in a legal battle over its secret collection of American telephone records. SAN FRANCISCO—A federal appeals court ruled on Tuesday that the NSA's telephone records collection programs were lawful under the 2008 Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act. In a 5–2 decision, a three-judge appeals panel said it was a "reasonable" interpretation of a legal provision that authorized the government to collect information about phone records from foreign intelligence agencies. The case, United States v. Edward Snowden, is the latest legal test of whether U.S. government surveillance programs can be trusted.

column1: This column was written by Henry Aaron . Behind closed doors all over Washington , serious people are working hard to try to change how Washington is run. We're trying to fix the biggest problem of our time: how much power does an unaccountable Congress wield? In the last decade, Congress has taken unprecedented steps to strip power from the president . The Constitution requires congressional approval of all federal bills and regulations . But the Constitution also says Congress has an unconstitutionally expansive power to change laws. That's why the Senate has a "power of reconciliation" — only the Senate can change any piece of legislation .
